metadata.title: Representation Learning of Compositional Data
metadata.author: Marta Avalos, Richard Nock, Cheng Soon Ong, Julien Rouar, Ke Sun
metadata.journal: Conference on Neural Information Processing Systems
metadata.abstract: We consider the problem of learning a low dimensional representation for compositional data. Compositional data consists of a collection of nonnegative data that sum to a constant value. Since the parts of the collection are statistically dependent, many standard tools cannot be directly applied. Instead, compositional data must be first transformed before analysis. Focusing on principal component analysis (PCA), we propose an approach that allows low dimensional representation learning directly from the original data. Our approach combines the benefits of the log-ratio transformation from compositional data analysis and exponential family PCA. A key tool in its derivation is a generalization of the scaled Bregman theorem, that relates the perspective transform of a Bregman divergence to the Bregman divergence of a perspective transform and a remainder conformal divergence. Our proposed approach includes a convenient surrogate (upper bound) loss of the exponential family PCA which has an easy to optimize form. We also derive the corresponding form for nonlinear autoencoders. Experiments on simulated data and microbiome data show the promise of our method.

highlights: Compositional data analysis (CoDA) is a subfield of statistics introduced more than three decades ago [3, 2, 1, 29]
Compositional data consist of a collection of nonnegative measurements that sum to a constant value, typically, proportions that sum to 1
We focus on Principal Components Analysis (PCA), one of the main tools for exploratory analysis of compositional data

To account for the nonlinearity due to the compositional nature of the data, we start from exponential family Principal Components Analysis [12] that we augment with the compositional constraint and simplify the loss to be optimized via a generalization of a recent result [25] on Bregman divergences, which may be of independent interest

We compare the following methods: clr-Principal Components Analysis means Principal Components Analysis applied on the centered log-ratio coordinates; Compositional data analysis-Principal Components Analysis is the proposed CODA-Principal Components Analysis in (11); SCoDA-Principal Components Analysis is the proposed S-CODA-Principal Components Analysis in (17); clr-AE is an autoencoder with L2 loss applied on the clr transformation; Compositional data analysis-AE is the proposed CODA-AUTOENCODER in subsection 5
We propose an approach for learning a low dimensional representation directly on raw count data, which is compositional in nature

For a dataset X which contains counts of strictly positive values, we reduce it to a compositional dataset by dividing out the totals, that is we compute the Compositional data analysis set X such that: xi = xi d j=1 xji is the vector of proportions for individual i
Principal Components Analysis has been generalized to the exponential families in a way that makes fitting occur in the natural parameter space [12, 19]

Remark In [3, Chapter 8], Compositional data analysis Principal Components Analysis is presented as a regular Principal Components Analysis over data that been subject to two transforms via the centered log-ratio coordinates

We compare the following methods: clr-Principal Components Analysis means Principal Components Analysis applied on the centered log-ratio coordinates; Compositional data analysis-Principal Components Analysis is the proposed CODA-Principal Components Analysis in (11); SCoDA-Principal Components Analysis is the proposed S-CODA-Principal Components Analysis in (17); clr-AE is an autoencoder with L2 loss applied on the clr transformation; Compositional data analysis-AE is the proposed CODA-AUTOENCODER in subsection 5

summary: Compositional data analysis (CoDA) is a subfield of statistics introduced more than three decades ago [3, 2, 1, 29].
[1] and [13] provided a framework to perform CoDA by mapping data from the constrained simplex space to the Euclidian space using nonlinear log-ratio transforms.

To account for the nonlinearity due to the compositional nature of the data, we start from exponential family PCA [12] that we augment with the compositional constraint and simplify the loss to be optimized via a generalization of a recent result [25] on Bregman divergences, which may be of independent interest.
Another way to apply dimension reduction is to perform a generalized PCA on crude count data.
PCA has been generalized to the exponential families in a way that makes fitting occur in the natural parameter space [12, 19].

If we wish to perform PCA on the crude count data, while maintaining the clr transform, we need an additional normalization term, which requires us to obtain a gauged version of the Bregman divergence.
The CoDA PCA is fitting natural parameters from centered log-ratios being natural coordinates as well.
We can define the CoDA PCA problem as follows.
Remark In [3, Chapter 8], CoDA PCA is presented as a regular PCA over data that been subject to two transforms via the centered log-ratio coordinates.

What Corollary 5 shows is that we can solve the problem via a surrogate formulation using non transformed data but minimizing a loss which is that of a φ-PCA transformed twice: first taking a perspective transform of the KL generator (KL) and having a weighted Bregman divergence minimization (g−1(.)).

One can redefine the gauge as g(x) = j:xj>01/ρ, where ρ = |{j : xj > 0}| so that g(x) is always positive and xis well defined on Sd ∪ ∂Sd. We compare the following methods: clr-PCA means PCA applied on the centered log-ratio coordinates; CoDA-PCA is the proposed CODA-PCA in (11); SCoDA-PCA is the proposed S-CODA-PCA in (17); clr-AE is an autoencoder with L2 loss applied on the clr transformation; CoDA-AE is the proposed CODA-AUTOENCODER in subsection 5.

Our proposed algorithm generalizes PCA in two ways, first by going to the exponential family via the Bregman divergence, and second by converting the normalization of data to a change in the Bregman divergence.
The key theorem used for transforming the Bregman divergence generalizes a recent result, and may be of independent interest.
headline: Focusing on principal component analysis , we propose an approach that allows low dimensional representation learning directly from the original data
